Yemen is a territory where a proxy war is being made between regional powers. As such, it is very likely that there will be a widespread violence against civilians by one of the internal sides of the conflict.

4971 people have been killed in Yemen from the beginning of March 2015 to June 23, 2017 ( http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=57052 ). That gives us approximately 2161 deaths a year which is well above 1000. Some of these may not be systematic killing and could only be accidental. If I played it safe and estimated that 50% of the deaths were systematic, then the death toll will still be over 1000 systematically killed civilians. Also, given that the death of Ali Abdullah Saleh will heighten conflicts, we are more likely to see an increase in civilian casualties.
